Graphical abstract Cyclooctyl PNN-Mn complex has been employed as a catalyst in the ATH of ketones with outstanding activity (up to 4000 TON) and high enantioselectivity (up to > 99 % ee). A new ferrocene-based chiral PNN pincer ligand (L1) was successfully applied in Mn-catalyzed asymmetric transfer hydrogenation (ATH) of ketones (37 examples), leading to high activities (up to 4000 TON with 48 h) and excellent enantioselectivities (up to >99 % ee) for their product alcohols. The combined coordination and catalytic studies led to the conclusion that PNN pincer ligand L1 proved higher enantioselectivity in ATH than that observed by PN bidentate analogue L0. Furthermore, DFT calculations and control experiments highlighted the significance of the cyclooctyl group among these cycloalkyl motifs in the Mn-catalysts, resulting in enhanced enantioselectivity (up to 99 % ee), and disclosed the stereocontrol with the assistance of an attractive aromatic π-π stacking interaction between substrate and catalyst in the catalytic process. Keywords Asymmetric transfer hydrogenation (ATH) Manganese(I) complexes Chiral PNN ligands Chiral alcohols Ketones Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Homogeneous asymmetric catalysis using chiral manganese complexes has gained a tremendous progress in the past decade [1], and continues to attract considerable attention from academic research community to industrial circles [2]. Indeed, the nature of manganese’s presenting lower toxicity concerns than precious metals, which can potentially lower energy consumption and purification cost in fine chemical processes [2,3]. Especially for the fields of asymmetric (transfer) hydrogenation (AH and ATH) based on such complexes [1a], the chiral alcohols via ATH and AH processes (Scheme 1 a) are of utmost importance to the flavor, fragrance, agrochemical, and pharmaceutical industries [4,5]. However, despite the promising results to date there are still some limitations and challenges in the asymmetric reduction approach with manganese. Specifically, the high loading (1–5 mol% Mn) of the catalyst required in most Mn(I)-catalyzed asymmetric reductions. In the term of the asymmetric reduction of ketone, their catalytic efficiency (TON ∼ 200 with 14 h) for ATH lags far behind that for AH (TON up to 10 000 with 24 h) (1, Scheme 1a) [1]. After the key early discoveries [1a,6], these advances in ATH have mainly been improved by ligand design that has seen both phosphine [4a,5b,7] and non-phosphine [8] containing chiral amine ligands emerge that when coordinated to manganese to form manganese bromide complex display both good activities and enantioselectivities. Notably, these active Mn-based catalysts are in situ generated from the complexation of corresponding chiral ligands with MnBr(CO)5 [8a,8b,9]. A good turnover number of 200 was reached over 14 h but a high TON might be accompanied by a lower enantioselectivities. [8f]. Meanwhile, lower attention is paid to the transformation of cationic tricarbonyl species to form actual active species (hydride Mn-complexes) [10]. For example, Clarke et al [4a] disclosed PNN-Mn cationic complexes (1, Scheme 1a) bearing a chiral phosphine incorporating a ferrocene moiety displayed high activity for ATH of acetophenone at 50 °C, and obtained medium stereoselectivities. Unfortunately, cationic manganese (I) complexes (2 and 3, Scheme 1b), [LPNN-Mn(CO)3]Br or [LPNNPMn(CO)2] Br, reported by Morris group, usually are inactive for ATH of ketones, which due to not allowing for the facile formation of an open site on the manganese center [3a]. In this context, revealing the start-up step and catalytic cycle mechanisms of catalysts and rational design of new ligands are equally important for improving catalytic performance in ATH system. More recently, as a promising strategy in ferrocenyl-phosphine chiral ligand design, our group has explored the fusion of carbocycles to the central pyridine unit in ligand to form well-defined Mn-based complexes bearing singly six-membered fused ring [3b]. This catalyst can not only enhance catalytic reactivity but also engender significant enantiocontrol in both the AH and ATH of ketones. In continuing our study [11–14], a cyclooctylpyridine-based pincer ligand [15] comprising both a cyclooctylpyridine fragment and a 1,2-substituted ferrocenyl-phosphine was explored for the ATH of ketones [3b]. It is envisaged that the steric properties of the larger eight-membered fused ring could impact on the mechanistic steps and the approach of the ketonic substrate during the catalysis. To complement this structural modification, the relative catalytic performance and capacity to impart enantiocontrol of PNN- (L1 and L2) and PN- (L0) ligands is also explored. The optimized PNN ligand (L1) is then assessed in the manganese-catalyzed ATH of a broad library of ketones using either the well-defined PNN-manganese complex (Mn1, Scheme 1c) or as part of an in-situ approach, in an effort to assess their relative catalytic performance/enantiocontrol. Additionally, DFT calculations are used to probe the transformation of cationic tricarbonyl species to actual active species and enantiocontrol which is complemented by targeted experimentation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 General information All manipulations and metal complexes were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques. All solvents were dried and distilled under nitrogen prior to use. All the liquid substrates and solid substrates were used directly without further purification. MnBr(CO)5 (CAS: 14516-54-2), (R)-N,N-dimethyl-1-ferrocenylethylamine, (R)-N,N-dimethyl-1-[(S)-2- (diphenylphosphino) ferrocenyl] ethylamine, (RC, SP) −1-(2- diphenylphosphino)ferrocenylethylamine, 6,7,8,9- tetrahydrocycloocta[b] pyridin-10(5H)-one [17] can be purchased from Shijiazhuang chiral chemical CO., LTD.. 1H, 13C and 31P NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker AV-400/500 NMR spectrometers. Chemical shift values in 1H and 13C NMR spectra were referenced internally to the residual solvent resonances, whereas 31P NMR spectra were referenced externally to H3PO4. Elemental analysis was carried out with a Vario EL Ⅲ CHN microanalyzer. Infrared spectroscopy was performed in the solid state on a Bruker ALPHA. GC analysis for Enantioselectivities (ee, %) was determined by an FuLi GC-9790Plus instrument using a chiral column [CP-Chirasil-Dex CB (25 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm)], flame ionization detector (FID) operating at 280 °C. Injector temperature was set at 250 °C. (120 °C isothermal for 2 min, 5 °C/min, 180 °C for 15 min. HPLC Chiral analysis for corresponding alcohol products was carried out on a Shimadzu instrument (Essential LC-15C) using a Chiralpak IB- N5 column (4.6 mm × 5 um × 250 mm). 2.2 Asymmetric transfer dehydrogenation studies Under a nitrogen atmosphere, (1) a mixture of MnBr(CO)5 (10 μmol, 2.7 mg) and Ligand (10 μmol) was dissolved in dry and degassed isopropanol (2 mL) and then stirred and heated to 80 °C for 4 h. (2) the corresponding ketone (5 mmol) was mixed with base (namely t-BuOK, t-BuONa, t-BuOLi, i-PrONa, EtONa, MeONa, MeOLi, HCOONa, KOH, NaOH, LiOH·H2O, CsCO3) (0.05–0.5 mmol), the in-situ generated complex added and the mixture dissolved in isopropanol (8–48 mL), which had been dried and degassed. stirred and heated to the desired temperature (10–80 °C). At the specified reaction time (24–48 h), 0.1 mL of the reaction mixture was sampled and immediately diluted with 0.5 mL of 2-propanol, dodecane introduced, before being analyzed by GC. The composition of the reaction mixture was confirmed by running GC of a mixture of pure ketone, alcohol and dodecane. The enantiomeric excess (ee) of the alcohol was determined by chiral HPLC or GC analysis. 2.3 ATH of ketones using in-situ generated Mn1 Under a nitrogen atmosphere, (1) a mixture of MnBr(CO)5 (10 μmol, 2.7 mg) and L1 (10 μmol) was dissolved in dry and degassed isopropanol (2 mL) and then stirred and heated to 80 °C for 4 h. (2) the corresponding ketone (5 mmol) was mixed with t-BuOK (11.2 mg, 1 mmol, 20 mol%), the in-situ generated Mn1 added and the mixture dissolved in isopropanol (8 mL), which had been dried and degassed. The reaction was stirred for the specified reaction time (20 h) at the desired temperature (30 °C). The reaction mixture was diluted with ethyl acetate (20 mL). The resulting residue was washed with an aqueous saturated solution of NaCl. Then, the resulting organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure and then purified by column chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 100/1 to 5/1) to afford the desired products. The enantiomeric excess (ee) was determined by GC using a CP-Chirasil-Dex CB column or by LC using a Chiralpak IB- N5 column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimizing reaction conditions In continuing our study of asymmetric reduction of ketones [3b,13b,13c], we previously reported the synthesis of PNN-pincer chiral ligand containing 1,2-disubstituted ferrocenyl unit and fused carbocyclic group of variable ring size (viz. six vs. seven) and their corresponding manganese complexes for the ATH of simple ketones. Realizing the systems with even larger or smaller fused cycloalkyl rings (viz. eight vs. five) for such reaction, (RC, RC, SP)-L1 and (RC, RC, SP)-L2 (See SI), which consist of a (Rc)-1-[(Sp)-2-diphenyl phosphino)ferrocenyl]ethylamine N-substituted with a (Rc)-5,6,7,8,9,10- hexahydrocycloocta[b]pyridine 10-yl (L1) or a (Rc)-6,7-dihydro-5H-cyclopenta[b]pyridine-7-yl (L2) group, have been readily prepared via a reductive amination approach from commercially available (RC,SP)-4 [3b,16] and ketones 5a – 5b [17] (see SI), respectively. Importantly, this approach allows the installation of the new (Rc)-stereogenic center in L1 and L2 in high diastereoselectivity [13b,18]. Firstly, the in-situ-generated Mn(I)-complex Mn1 from L1, as a test catalyst was in detail explored for the ATH transformation of a1 to S-1-phenylethanol (b1). Initially, a variety of organic and inorganic bases, including t-BuOK, t-BuONa, t-BuOLi, i-PrONa, EtONa, MeONa, MeOLi, HCOONa, KOH, NaOH, LiOH·H2O, Cs2CO3 was tested in ATH of a1 for establishing the most compatible base (Table S1). As shown Scheme 2 a, it was found that the type of base employed has a marked effect on the yields and enantiomeric excess of S-1-phenylethanol with t-BuOK or t-BuOLi as the more standout performer. Among these twelve bases, besides HCOONa and Cs2CO3, most of these displayed good enantioselectivities for ATH of acetophenone with ee values of S-b1 more than 80 % (Orange column, Scheme 2a) and offered the yields of S-b1 in the range of 65–96 % (green column). After identifying the better compatible base in our above evaluation, we next set out to examine the influence of different temperatures (Table S2, See SI). MnBr(CO)5/L1 was evaluated at temperatures between 25 °C and 50 °C with t-BuOK or t-BuOLi as base. All cases were found to promote ATH reaction, yielding products in the range of 81–99 %. However, higher temperatures were found to be unfavorable for enantioselectivity. Indeed, the optimum temperature was determined to be 30 °C affording b1 in 96 % conversion and 83 % ee. Furthermore, t-BuOK displayed higher stereoselectivity in ATH of a1 than that case of t-BuOLi. To explore the effect of pyridine fragment and the ring size of the carbocyclic group in the PNN ligand on performance, complexes derived from the reaction of MnBr(CO)5 with L1 – L2 and L0 were screened in situ using the optimized reaction conditions established for Mn(CO)5Br/L1 (Scheme 2b). Notably, these three complexes displayed high activities for the reduction of a1, with the enantiomeric excess of b1 with respect to the chiral ligand falling in the order: L1 (83 %) > L0 (64 %) > L2 (21 %). The strained amino-cyclopenta[b]pyridine-based L2 displayed the lowest enantioselectivity in ATH of a1 due to spatial constraints caused by the five-membered ring [15a,19]. Furthermore, we sought to examine the influence of the amount of t-BuOK for such reaction, varying the usage of t-BuOK from 10 mol% to 30 mol% and the temperature fixed at 30 °C (Table S3), the optimal amount was found to be 20 mol%, leading to the highest enantioselectivity of 83 % ee (entry 5, Table S3). With the optimized conditions in hand, the further comparison of catalytic performance for the ATH of a1 regarding the activity and enantioselectivity between in-situ generated complexes (Mn0 and Mn1) derived from L0 and L1 varying the temperature from 25 °C to 80 °C was explored (Fig. 1 ). When L1 was employed in such reaction, all these cases were converted to b1 (83–98 %) with good to high enantiomeric excess (79–87 % ee) with the exception at 60 °C and 80 °C. By contrast, only moderate enantiomeric excess (61–69 % ee) to the alcohols were obtained when using L0 but with nonetheless comparable conversions (84 – 98 %) to that seen with L1, which highlighted the superiority of tridentate ligands over their original bidentate ligands in ATH reaction [20]. Given the higher enantioselectivities seen using in-situ generated Mn1, we decided to focus our subsequent efforts on using Mn1 as the catalyst to screen other methyl-aryl ketones and propiophenones. For purposes of comparison, tests using pre-prepared Mn0 from L0 were performed alongside. As shown in Table 1 , when Mn1 was employed in the ATH reactions, except for 2′-methylacetophenone (a2), all the ketones were completely converted to the desired alcohols (85–99 %) with good to excellent enantioselectivities (83–98 % ee). In contrast, when Mn0 was used as the catalyst, not only lower yields (82–99 %) of the alcohols achieved, but also displayed lower enantioselectivities (41–71 % ee). For example, the relative ee values increases of products b1, b2, b6, b9, b25 and b26 were 21 %, 20 %, 26 %, 27 %, 41 % and 46 %, respectively, showing a tendency of enantioselectivity to increase using L1 as ligand replaces of L0, which highlighted the outperformance of L1 in ATH reaction. 3.2 Substrate scope using in-situ generated Mn1 as catalyst To explore the substrate scope and the versatility of in-situ generated Mn1, a wider variety of aryl alkyl ketones (a2 – a32) and heteroaromatic ketones (a33 – a37) were selected for study in the ATH using the optimal conditions established (viz., ketone: t-BuOK: [Mn] = 100: 20: 2, in dry i-PrOH at 30 °C) to gain a broader understanding of catalytic performance and enantiocontrol (Scheme 3 ). Generally, Mn1 demonstrated good tolerance towards a wide range of functional groups, including Me, OMe F, Cl, Br and CF3, affording the corresponding chiral alcohols with good to excellent yields and enantiomeric excess (b2 – b37). For aryl methyl ketones (a2 – a21), it seems that there is no unambiguous correlation between the electron property of substituents on the phenyl ring and the yield of products. Various monosubstituted acetophenones (a2 – a16) were smoothly reduced to the desired chiral alcohols (b2 – b16) with good to excellent enantiomeric excess (76–93 % ee) and moderate to excellent GC-yields (39–99 %). With regard to ortho-substituted acetophenones (a2 – a5), 2-bromoacetophenone (a5) is enantioselectively. reduced to give b5 with lowest yield when compared to its analogues (b2 – b4); 2-methylacetophenone (a2) gave higher enantioselectivity (91 % ee) than that observed in a3 – a5 (83–85 % ee). Notably, in case of meta-substituted acetophenones (a2 – a5) as substrates, ee values up to 85 % were observed at nearly quantitative yields. Furthermore, para-substituted acetophenones (a11 – a16) could be transformed into chiral alcohols, in which CF3 substrate a16 led to the best enantioselectivity (93 % ee). Gave these results from the substitution pattern on the benzene ring, it was found that enantioselectivities generally varied in the order: meta (85–93 % ee) > ortho (83–91 % ee) > para (76–93 % ee). For example, 92 % ee was obtained for ATH of 3-chloroacetophenone (a9), which is 16 %, 7 % higher than its para- and meta-substituted analogues (a4 and a14), respectively. Interestingly, the disubstituted acetophenone derivatives (a17–a19) bearing electron-withdrawing substituents (R = F, Cl and CF3) were more effectively and stereoselectively converted to their corresponding alcohols (b17 – b19) than that observed by their analogues containing electron-donating groups (a20 and a21, R = Me and –OCH2O-). Either para − or meta −substituted propiophenones (a22 – a26) could be fully converted to the corresponding 1-phenylpropan-1-ols (b22 – b26) with good to high ee’s (85–98 % ee). When compared to the 3- and 4-chloroacetophenones (a9 and a14), similarly chloropropiophenones (a22 and a25), afforded chiral alcohols with higher degrees of enantiomeric excess. Evidently, no dehalogenation of halide-containing substrates occurred. Moreover, ketonic substrates with longer chain alkyl groups (a27 – a28) were conducive to forming the target alcohols with high enantioselectivities (96 % and 82 % ee). In terms of steric effects, increasing the steric hindrance on the alkyl group (e.g. isobutyrophenone b29) led to both the conversion and ee’s significantly decreasing (b29 89 %, 70 % ee). Furthermore, Mn1 was able to mediate effectively the hydrogenation of naphthyl/anthranyl-methyl ketones (a31 – a33) with good yields (91–99 %) and enantiomeric excess (83–99 % ee). In additions, furyl-, thiophenyl-substrates (a34 – a37) can be efficiently reduced to the desired alcohols with good to high ee’s (68 – 93 %). Unlike the case of CyP2N4-Mn(I) reported by Li [9], this system is active for furanyl derivatives with 2-acetylfuran (a33) easily reduced to it corresponding chiral secondary alcohol (b34), with good conversion and high ee. Notably, increasing the number of phenyl groups in the substrate enhances the enantioselectivity for the formation of the product as exemplified by phenyl(thiophen-2-yl)methanone (a35) which affords the corresponding secondary alcohol (b35) with higher enantiomeric excess than phenyl-free 2-acetylfuran (a33); a finding that could be related to the π-π stacking effects noted in the DFT calculations (vide infra). 3.3 Mechanism study To allow a detailed understanding of potential manganese active species and enantiocontrol in this catalytic system, we carried out a series of control experiments and DFT calculations. Further computational details are provided in the ESI. Firstly, to elucidate the structure of in situ formed active catalyst (Scheme 4 , See SI), we sought to isolate the complexes (Mn1 and Mn2) formed upon complexation of L1/L2 to Mn(CO)5Br. The cationic complexes [(L1/L2)Mn(CO)3]Br (Mn1 and Mn2) were readily formed at 110 °C in dry toluene for 12 h or at 80 °C in dry i-PrOH for 4 h. Mn1 and Mn2 were fully characterized using multinuclear NMR, FT-IR, elemental analysis, and single-crystal X-ray analysis (See SI). Notably, Mn1 could be readily confirmed in the CO region in its IR spectrum (2026, 1950, 1908 cm−1) which also corresponds to the number of CO ligands bound to Mn1. Similarly, its 31P NMR spectrum proved informative with the signal for the coordinated phosphine in Mn1 appearing at 41.77 ppm which compares to −24.05 ppm for L1. Further confirmation of the structural of Mn1 was provided by single crystal X-ray determinations, which revealed a clear structure based on adistorted-octahedral coordination geometry in which the three P, N and N donor atoms in (Rc, Sp, Rc,)-L1 to the metal center in a fac-configuration with the coordination sphere of the cationic complex completed by three carbonyl ligands (Scheme 4a). Within the saturated section of the eight membered rings the expected nonplanar puckered arrangement is adopted. Based on DFT calculations, Mn1 is more stable than Mn-Br by 6.2 kcal/mol (Figure S34). Unlike the case of Morris’s work [3a], investigating the transformation of Mn1 to manganese active species in i-PrOH for mechanism studies we found that Mn1 easily was converted to Mn1′ with a sharper 31P NMR spectrum (85.38 ppm) after treatment with 5 eq. t-BuOK [3b,5b]. Unfortunately, attempts to obtain a crystal structure of this complex failed after many trials. Then, the in situ generated complex, and isolated Mn1 and Mn1′ were selected as catalysts for ATH of acetophenone (a1), fortunately, similar to the in-situ generated complex, high yield and ee value were observed by isolated Mn1 (96 % yield, 89 % ee) and Mn1′ (75 % yield, 78 % ee) (Scheme 4c). Following a series of experiments for screening of Mn1 loading (see Table S5), it was showed that ee suffers a bit if catalyst loadings are reduced below 1 mol%, although reasonable conversion can be achieved using lower loadings with TON up to 4000 (67 % ee based on S/C ratio of 10,000:1 with 48 h). Furthermore, an investigation using deuterated i-PrOH was explored for identifying D incorporation of b1 using Mn1 as catalyst. 1-Phenethylalcohol b1 (90 % yield) was formed with the CH resonances appearing at δ 7.44–7.30 (m, 5H) and δ 4.90 (q, 0.00H) in the 1H NMR spectrum. The methylene (CH) signal at δ 4.90 suggests that hydrides in the b1 were entirely substituted by deuterium (100 %), which indicated that the catalytic system is capable to transfer the hydrogen source from deuterated i-PrOH to the substrate [13b] and rules substrate’s enolization out but involves Mn hydride species intermediate during the transfer hydrogenation process. Secondly, to cast some light on the superiority of the cyclooctyl group among these cycloalkyl motifs (six to eight-membered rings) in the Mn-catalysts, we conducted control experiments (Fig. 2 ) to probe the significance of the cyclooctyl group in L1 during the ATH of a1 using in situ generated Mn1 as catalyst. Notably, the relative level of activity fell in the order: A > B > C > L1 at either 25 °C or 40 °C. In contrast, the relative value of ee fell in the order: L1 > A > B > C, which highlighted that the Mn1 could maintain higher enantioselectivity at higher temperature compared with the catalysts without 8-membered ring. Thirdly, to deeply understand the origin of the stereoselective asymmetric hydrogenation reaction of ketones catalyzed by Mn complexes (Mn-A, Mn-B and Mn1) containing pincer ligands (A, B and L1), DFT calculations (the PCM M06-L//B3LYP-D3 method) were carried out. Our DFT results revealed that the free energy barriers of hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) for the formation of (R)-type chiral products with these catalysts (Mn-A, Mn-B and Mn1) were calculated to be higher than those for (S)-type chiral products, with a ΔΔG of 1.0 − 4.0 kcal/mol (Fig. 3 a). In comparison to (R)-type chiral product, the generation of the (S) product catalyzed by complex (Mn-A, Mn-B and Mn1) is favored through transition state (ATS, BTS and Mn1TS). Notably, the Gibbs free energies (ΔG) of transition states (ATS, BTS and Mn1TS) fell in the order: ATS (12.5 kcal/mol) < BTS (13.3 kcal/mol) < Mn1TS (16.1 kcal/mol); the free energy difference (ΔΔG) in three catalysts fell in the order: Mn-B (1.0 kcal/mol) < Mn-A (1.8 kcal/mol) < Mn1 (4.0 kcal/mol). Other DFT methods give the similar results (Table S8). These DFT results are qualitatively consistent with experimental observations. Furthermore, the noncovalent interactions (NCIs) and distortion-interaction energy analysis show that the corresponding change of free energy difference (ΔΔG) is mainly ascribed to the π-π stacking effects between the phenyl of substrate (a1) and pyridyl, cycloalkyl groups in the ligands (Fig. 3c). In the steric maps, the steric hindrance from the cycloalkyl group in the ligands does change significantly (buried volume 55 % vs 59 % in the northeast quadrant), which is consistent with the crystal structure of these complexes [3b,13b]. Overall, our computed results indicate that the formation of the S-type chiral product and the enantioselectivity are mainly influenced by attractive π-π stacking. 4 Conclusions A new PNN-Mn(I) catalyst containing ferrocene-based chiral PNP pincer ligand with controllable cyclooctyl motif has been developed, enabling the asymmetrical transfer hydrogenation of aryl alkyl ketones and heteroaromatic ketones with high activity and enantioselectivity (up to 99 % ee). Compared to its analogues PN bidentate ligand (L0) and smaller cycloalkyl PNN-pincer ligands (A – B and L2), cyclooctyl-modified PNN ligand enables as a rigid area and a relatively flexible area in the chiral pocket, which leads to an effective enantiomeric discrimination in the hydride transfer step, enhanced enantioselectivity in ATH reaction. Further applications of this methodology in asymmetrical reductions of other unsaturated compounds (imines and olefins) are underway in our lab. coredata.dc:description: A new ferrocene-based chiral PNN pincer ligand (L1) was successfully applied in Mn-catalyzed asymmetric transfer hydrogenation (ATH) of ketones (37 examples), leading to high activities (up to 4000 TON with 48 h) and excellent enantioselectivities (up to >99 % ee) for their product alcohols. The combined coordination and catalytic studies led to the conclusion that PNN pincer ligand L1 proved higher enantioselectivity in ATH than that observed by PN bidentate analogue L0. Furthermore, DFT calculations and control experiments highlighted the significance of the cyclooctyl group among these cycloalkyl motifs in the Mn-catalysts, resulting in enhanced enantioselectivity (up to 99 % ee), and disclosed the stereocontrol with the assistance of an attractive aromatic π-π stacking interaction between substrate and catalyst in the catalytic process.

coredata.dc:title: Enhancing enantioselectivity of manganese catalyst for asymmetric transfer hydrogenation of ketones through P,N,N-chelation of a cyclooctyl pyridine
